defs.docs:
`linregress` provides an easy to use implementation of ordinary
  least squared linear regression with some basic statistics.
  See [`RegressionModel`] for details.

defs.name: InconsistentSlopes
defs.docs: Number of slopes and output names is inconsistent.

attributes.value: / Number of slopes and output names is inconsistent.

defs.name: NoData
defs.docs: Cannot fit model without data.

defs.name: NoFormula
defs.docs: Cannot fit model without formula or data columns.

attributes.value: / Cannot fit model without formula or data columns.

defs.name: InvalidFormula
defs.docs: Given formula is invalid.

defs.name: InvalidDataColumns
defs.docs: Given data columns are invalid.

defs.name: BothFormulaAndDataColumnsGiven
defs.docs: You must specify either a formula or data columns.

attributes.value: / You must specify either a formula or data columns.

defs.docs: Requested column is not in data. (Column given as String)

defs.docs: A column used in the model is misising from the provided data

defs.name: RegressorRegressandDimensionMismatch
defs.docs: Regressor and regressand dimensions do not match. (Column given as String)

attributes.value: / Regressor and regressand dimensions do not match. (Column given as String)

defs.docs: Error while processing the regression data. (Details given as String)

attributes.value: / Error while processing the regression data. (Details given as String)

defs.docs: The given vectors have inconsistent lengths

attributes.value: / The given vectors have inconsistent lengths

defs.name: InconsistentRegressionModel
defs.docs: The RegressionModel internal state is inconsistent

attributes.value: / The RegressionModel internal state is inconsistent

defs.name: Error
defs.value:
pub enum Error {
    InconsistentSlopes(InconsistentSlopes),
    NoData,
    NoFormula,
    InvalidFormula,
    InvalidDataColumns,
    BothFormulaAndDataColumnsGiven,
    ColumnNotInData(String),
    ModelColumnNotInData(String),
    RegressorRegressandDimensionMismatch(String),
    RegressionDataError(String),
    ModelFittingError(String),
    InconsistentVectors,
    InconsistentRegressionModel,
}
defs.docs: An error that can occur in this crate.

attributes.value: / An error that can occur in this crate.
/ Generally this error corresponds to problems with input data or fitting

defs.name: FormulaRegressionBuilder
defs.docs: A builder to create and fit a linear regression model.

attributes.value: / A builder to create and fit a linear regression model.
/ Given a dataset and a set of columns to use this builder
/ will produce an ordinary least squared linear regression model.
/ See [`formula`] and [`data`] for details on how to configure this builder.
/ The pseudo inverse method is used to fit the model.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create as new FormulaRegressionBuilder with no data or formula set.

attributes.value: / Create as new FormulaRegressionBuilder with no data or formula set.

defs.name: data
defs.docs: Set the data to be used for the regression.

attributes.value: / Set the data to be used for the regression.
/ The data has to be given as a reference to a [`RegressionData`] struct.

defs.name: formula
defs.value: pub fn formula<T: Into<Cow>>(Self, T) -> Self
defs.docs: Set the formula to use for the regression.

attributes.value: / Set the formula to use for the regression.
/ E.g. for a regressand named Y and three regressors named A, B and C
/ the correct format would be `Y ~ A + B + C`.
/ Note that there is currently no special support for categorical variables.
/ So if you have a categorical variable with more than two distinct values
/ or values that are not `0` and `1` you will need to perform "dummy coding" yourself.

defs.name: data_columns
defs.value:
pub fn data_columns<I, S1, S2>(Self, S1, I) -> Self where I: IntoIterator<Item
= S2>, S1: Into<Cow>, S2: Into<Cow>
defs.docs: Set the columns to be used as regressand and regressors for the regression.

attributes.value: / Set the columns to be used as regressand and regressors for the regression.
/ Note that there is currently no special support for categorical variables.
/ So if you have a categorical variable with more than two distinct values
/ or values that are not `0` and `1` you will need to perform "dummy coding" yourself.

defs.name: fit
defs.docs:
Fits the model and returns a [`RegressionModel`] if successful.
 You need to set the data with [`data`] and a formula with [`formula`]
 before you can use it.

attributes.value: / Fits the model and returns a [`RegressionModel`] if successful.
/ You need to set the data with [`data`] and a formula with [`formula`]

defs.name: fit_without_statistics
defs.docs:
Like [`fit`] but does not perfom any statistics on the resulting model.
 Returns a [`RegressionParameters`] struct containing the model parameters
 if successfull.

attributes.value: / Like [`fit`] but does not perfom any statistics on the resulting model.
/ Returns a [`RegressionParameters`] struct containing the model parameters
/ This is usefull if you do not care about the statistics or the model and data
/ you want to fit result in too few residual degrees of freedom to perform

defs.name: RegressionData
defs.docs: A container struct for the regression data.

attributes.value: / A container struct for the regression data.
/ This struct is obtained using a [`RegressionDataBuilder`].

defs.name: RegressionDataBuilder
defs.docs: A builder to create a RegressionData struct for use with a [`FormulaRegressionBuilder`].

attributes.value: / A builder to create a RegressionData struct for use with a [`FormulaRegressionBuilder`].

defs.docs: Create a new [`RegressionDataBuilder`].

defs.name: invalid_value_handling
defs.docs:
Configure how to handle non real `f64` values (NaN or infinity or negative infinity) using
 a variant of the [`InvalidValueHandling`] enum.

attributes.value: / Configure how to handle non real `f64` values (NaN or infinity or negative infinity) using

defs.name: build_from
defs.value:
pub fn build_from<'a, I, S>(Self, I) -> Result<RegressionData, Error> where
I: IntoIterator<Item = (S, Vec<f64>)>, S: Into<Cow>
defs.docs: Build a [`RegressionData`] struct from the given data.

attributes.value: / Build a [`RegressionData`] struct from the given data.
/ Any type that implements the [`IntoIterator`] trait can be used for the data.
/ This could for example be a [`Hashmap`] or a [`Vec`].
/ The iterator must consist of tupels of the form `(S, Vec<f64>)` where
/ `S` is a type that implements `Into<Cow<str>>`, such as [`String`] or [`str`].
/ You can think of this format as the representation of a table of data where
/ each tuple `(S, Vec<f64>)` represents a column. The `S` is the header or label of the
/ column and the `Vec<f64>` contains the data of the column.
/ Because `~` and `+` are used as separators in the formula they may not be used in the name

defs.name: ReturnError
defs.docs: Return an error to the caller.

attributes.value: / Return an error to the caller.

defs.name: DropInvalid
defs.docs: Drop the columns containing the invalid values.

attributes.value: / Drop the columns containing the invalid values.

defs.name: InvalidValueHandling
defs.docs: How to proceed if given non real `f64` values (NaN or infinity or negative infinity).

attributes.value: / How to proceed if given non real `f64` values (NaN or infinity or negative infinity).

defs.name: RegressionModel
defs.value: RegressionModel { parameters, se, ssr, rsquared, rsquared_adj, pvalues, residuals, scale }
defs.docs: A fitted regression model.

attributes.value: / If a field has only one value for the model it is given as `f64`.
/ Otherwise it is given as a [`RegressionParameters`] struct.

defs.name: parameters
defs.docs: The model's intercept and slopes (also known as betas).

attributes.value: / The model's intercept and slopes (also known as betas).

defs.name: se
defs.docs: The standard errors of the parameter estimates.

attributes.value: / The standard errors of the parameter estimates.

defs.name: ssr
defs.docs: Sum of squared residuals.

defs.name: rsquared
defs.docs: R-squared of the model.

defs.name: rsquared_adj
defs.docs: Adjusted R-squared of the model.

defs.name: pvalues
defs.docs: The two-tailed p-values for the t-statistics of the params.

attributes.value: / The two-tailed p-values for the t-statistics of the params.

defs.name: residuals
defs.docs: The residuals of the model.

defs.name: scale
defs.docs: A scale factor for the covariance matrix.

attributes.value: /  A scale factor for the covariance matrix.
/  Note that the square root of `scale` is often
/  called the standard error of the regression.

defs.name: predict
defs.value:
pub fn predict<'a, I, S>(&Self, I) -> Result<Vec<f64>, Error> where
I: IntoIterator<Item = (S, Vec<f64>)>, S: Into<Cow>
defs.docs: Evaluates the model on given new input data and returns the predicted values.

attributes.value: / Evaluates the model on given new input data and returns the predicted values.
/ The new data is expected to have the same columns as the original data.
/ See [`RegressionDataBuilder.build`] for details on the type of the `new_data` parameter.
/ This function does *no* special handling of non real values (NaN or infinity or negative infinity).
/ Such a value in `new_data` will result in a corresponding meaningless prediction.

defs.name: LowLevelRegressionModel
defs.value: LowLevelRegressionModel { parameters, se, ssr, rsquared, rsquared_adj, pvalues, residuals, scale }
defs.docs: A fitted regression model

attributes.value: / If a field has only one value for the model it is given as `f64`.
/ Otherwise it  is given as a `Vec<f64>` where the first value is the intercept value.

defs.name: parameters
defs.docs: The model's intercept and slopes (also known as betas).

defs.name: se
defs.docs: The standard errors of the parameter estimates.

defs.docs: Sum of squared residuals.

defs.docs: R-squared of the model.

defs.docs: Adjusted R-squared of the model.

defs.docs: The residuals of the model.

defs.name: scale
defs.docs: A scale factor for the covariance matrix.

attributes.value: /  A scale factor for the covariance matrix.
/  Note that the square root of `scale` is often
/  called the standard error of the regression.

defs.name: RegressionParameters
defs.docs: A parameter of a fitted [`RegressionModel`] given for the intercept and each regressor.

attributes.value: / A parameter of a fitted [`RegressionModel`] given for the intercept and each regressor.
/ The values and names of the regressors are given in the same order.
/ You can obtain name value pairs using [`pairs`].

defs.name: pairs
defs.docs: Returns the parameters as a Vec of tuples of the form `(name: &str, value: f64)`.

attributes.value: / Returns the parameters as a Vec of tuples of the form `(name: &str, value: f64)`.

defs.name: fit_low_level_regression_model
defs.value:
pub fn fit_low_level_regression_model(&[f64], usize, usize)
-> Result<LowLevelRegressionModel, Error>
defs.docs: Fit a regression model directly on a matrix of input data

attributes.value: / Fit a regression model directly on a matrix of input data
/ Expects a matrix in the format
/ - The matrix should already contain the `intercept` column consisting of only the value `1.0`.
/ - No validation of the data is performed, except for a simple dimension consistency check.

defs.name: fit_low_level_regression_model_without_statistics
defs.value:
pub fn fit_low_level_regression_model_without_statistics(&[f64], usize, usize)
-> Result<Vec<f64>, Error>
defs.docs:
Like [`fit_low_level_regression_model`] but does not compute any statistics after
 fitting the model.

attributes.value: / Like [`fit_low_level_regression_model`] but does not compute any statistics after
/ Returns a `Vec<f64>` analogous to the `parameters` field of [`LowLevelRegressionModel`].
